Priya Srivastava, TIMESOFINDIA.COM, TRAVEL TRENDS, WORLD
                                    Updated :  Jun 30, 2024, 09:39 IST

Every country in this world is blessed with natural wonders such as waterfalls, animals, trees, birds and mountains which are unique to that particular nation. Native animals form an essential part of a country's topography and attraction as a tourist destination. From the majestic Bengal Tiger of India to the Bald Eagle of the United States, animals symbolise the natural identity and heritage of their respective countries. Each animal with its unique characteristics, plays an important role in its ecosystem, reflecting the values and conservation efforts of the nation it represents. On this note, let’s have a look at national animals of 10 different countries and some interesting facts about those animals.

The Markhor, or Capra falconeri, is the national animal of Pakistan. Known for their striking spiral horns, they symbolize the country's rugged mountainous regions. Renowned for their impressive climbing skills, they are often seen scaling steep cliffs.

The Bengal Tiger or Panthera tigris tigris is India's proud national animal. It symbolises strength, power and grace. The tiger is noted for its stunning orange and black stripes. Fact: Bengal Tiger is also the largest tiger subspecies in the world and it plays an important role in maintaining the balance of ecosystems.

The Bengal tiger or Panthera tigris tigris is the national animal of Bangladesh. This handsome animal is known for its swimming abilities and is known to inhabit the mangrove forests of the Sundarbans. Fact: The Bengal Tiger symbolises the country’s rich biodiversity and the importance of preserving its natural habitats.

The Bald eagle or Haliaeetus leucocephalus is the national animal of the United States. The animal with its striking white head and powerful beak is a symbol of freedom. It is known for its impressive aerial acrobatics and keen eyesight, capable of spotting fish from great heights. Fact: It used to be endangered due to habitat loss and pesticide use, but the bald eagle has made a remarkable recovery.

The kangaroo or Macropus rufus is Australia's largest marsupial and the national animal of Australia. The animal is noted for its distinctive red-brown fur and powerful hind legs. Fact: Kangaroos are capable of walking at high speeds, covering distances of up to 9 m in a single leap.

Beaver or Castor canadensis is Canada's national animal. Known for its exceptional building skills, beavers construct intricate dams and lodges using branches, mud, and rocks. Their sharp teeth continually grow throughout their lives. Fact: Beavers are essential in maintaining healthy wetland ecosystems across Canada.

The giant panda or Ailuropoda melanoleuca is synonymous with China's commitment to wildlife conservation. The national animal of China is noted for its black and white fur. These cute animals primarily feed on bamboo and are adept climbers. Fact: Despite being beloved worldwide, giant pandas were once endangered due to habitat loss and low reproduction rates.
The Lion or Panthera leo is the national animal of the UK. It can be seen on the royal coat of arms, representing courage and monarchy. Lions are social animals, living in prides.
Fact: Lions, the apex predators, once roamed across Europe and Asia but now thrive mainly in Africa.

This makes it extremely important to take preventive measures during monsoon season to prevent the risk of dengue. Here are a few tips:
Getty Images

Dengue symptoms include sudden onset of high fever, severe headache, pain behind the eyes, joint and muscle pain, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and skin rash. In severe cases, dengue can lead to hemorrhagic fever, bleeding, abdominal pain, vomiting, and difficulty breathing.
Getty Images
Remove stagnant water sources such as containers, flower pots, and old tires where mosquitoes breed. Regularly empty and clean water storage containers to prevent larvae from developing.
Getty Images
Apply mosquito repellent containing DEET, picaridin, or oil of lemon eucalyptus on exposed skin when outdoors, especially during dawn and dusk when mosquitoes are most active.
Getty Images
Wear long-sleeved shirts, pants, socks, and closed shoes to minimize exposed skin and reduce the risk of mosquito bites, particularly in areas with high mosquito activity.
Getty Images
Use screens on windows and doors to prevent mosquitoes from entering indoor spaces. Repair any holes or tears in screens to ensure they are effective barriers.
Getty Images
Sleep under mosquito nets, especially if you live in or are traveling to areas with a high prevalence of dengue. Ensure the nets are properly tucked in and do not have any holes.
Getty Images
Maintain a clean and well-maintained environment both indoors and outdoors. Trim tall grass and bushes, and dispose of garbage properly to reduce potential mosquito resting and breeding sites.
Getty Images
Participate in community-based mosquito control programs. Collaborate with neighbors to collectively eliminate breeding sites and implement preventive measures in shared spaces.
Getty Images
Stay informed about dengue outbreaks and avoid traveling to regions experiencing high transmission rates of the virus. If travel is unavoidable, take extra precautions to prevent mosquito bites.
Getty Images

Consult healthcare professionals for guidance on dengue prevention, particularly if you have a weakened immune system or are pregnant. They can provide personalized advice and recommend appropriate preventive measures.
Getty Images

After leading India to victory in the T20 World Cup 2024, Rohit Sharma announced his retirement from T20Is, becoming the third Indian captain to achieve a World Cup trophy. Rohit holds the record for the most runs in T20Is at the time of his retirement. He was the second-highest run-scorer in the T20 World Cup 2024 and has been a part of every T20 World Cup since 2007.
Image Source: PTI

​After India's ICC T20 World Cup 2024 triumph, Ravindra Jadeja retired from T20 international cricket, following teammates Virat Kohli and Rohit Sharma. He announced his decision on social media a day after the victory but confirmed his commitment to Test and ODI formats. Jadeja's T20I career from 2009 to 2024 saw him play 74 matches, scoring 515 runs and taking 54 wickets with his left-arm spin. His retirement marks the end of a significant era, contributing both with bat and ball for the Indian team in T20Is.
Image Source: ANI
Two-time T20 World Cup Player of the Tournament and Player of the Match in the 2024 final, Virat Kohli, announced his retirement from T20I cricket. He bows out as the second-highest T20I run-scorer.
Image Source: ANI

South African wicket-keeper Heinrich Klaasen announced his retirement from Test cricket on January 8, 2024, to focus on limited-overs formats. Klaasen, who debuted against India in October 2019, played just three more Tests, scoring a total of 108 runs. His final Test was against West Indies at the Wanderers in March 2023.
Image Source: Agencies

​Dean Elgar, the South African opener, retired from international cricket before the Test series against India in December-January 2023-24. Elgar, who played 86 Tests and 8 ODIs, featured in his final match in the New Year's Test at Newlands, Cape Town. In 2024, he was the first international cricketer to retire. Over his 86-match Test career, he scored 5347 runs at an average of 37.92, with 14 centuries and 23 half-centuries. Elgar also captained South Africa in 18 Tests, winning 9 and losing 8.
Image Source: Agencies

​Neil Wagner, the left-arm seamer from New Zealand, retired from international cricket this year after a distinguished career spanning 2012 to 2024. He played 64 Test matches, claiming 260 wickets. Wagner played a pivotal role in New Zealand's successes, notably contributing to their victory over India in the World Test Championship final in 2021. His impactful performances and contributions will be fondly remembered by fans and teammates alike.
Image Source: Agencies

In May 2024, Colin Munro, the New Zealand opener, retired from international cricket after not being selected for the T20 World Cup 2024 squad. His last T20I match for New Zealand was in 2020, playing a total of 65 matches in the format.Despite missing out on the T20 World Cups in 2021 and 2022, Munro remained hopeful of selection by staying active in franchise cricket. Alongside his T20I career, Munro represented New Zealand in 57 ODIs and one Test match.
Image Source: Agencies

Kedar Jadhav, aged 39, announced his retirement from all forms of cricket in June this year. Hailing from Pune, he represented India in 73 ODIs and nine T20Is. During his career, he scored two ODI centuries and six fifties, and was a part of the 2019 World Cup squad. His final appearance for India was in 2020.
Image Source: Agencies

​Dinesh Karthik, a seasoned Indian cricketer, announced his retirement from all forms of cricket, including the IPL. Karthik's career spanned over two decades, starting in the 2002/03 season. Despite competition from MS Dhoni, he represented India in 94 ODIs, 60 T20Is, and 26 Tests. His final national team appearance was in the 2022 T20 World Cup.In the IPL, Karthik played 256 matches, participating in every season until this year.
Image Source: Agencies

David Warner, the Australian opener, retired from Test cricket in June 2023 during the Ashes series in England, concluding his career against Pakistan in Australia. He also retired from ODIs after the ICC Cricket World Cup 2023 final against India on November 19, 2023. Warner played 112 Tests, scoring 8786 runs, and 161 ODIs, amassing 6932 runs with 48 centuries across formats. In his final Test series, Australia whitewashed Pakistan in December 2023-January 2024. Warner retired from T20Is after the ICC T20 World Cup 2024, where Australia exited in the Super 8 round in June 2024.
Image Source: Getty Images

​Trent Boult, a stalwart of New Zealand cricket, retired from international cricket following the team's disappointing performance in the recent T20 World Cup. His 13-year career concluded quietly at the tournament. Boult's achievements include 317 Test wickets in 78 matches, ranking fourth among New Zealand's top wicket-takers. His partnership with Tim Southee, who has 380 Test wickets, was pivotal for New Zealand's bowling.
Image Source: ANI

TRAVEL TRENDS, PUNE
                                         Created : Jul 2, 2024, 09:00 IST

Pune has some beautiful and serene beaches within a few hours’ drive that offer the perfect retreat. These beaches provide a tranquil environment where one can just unwind, relax, and enjoy the natural beauty of the coastline. If you are in Pune or are planning to visit this destination in the near future, bookmark these six quiet beaches near Pune that promise a peaceful getaway.

Located around 170 km from Pune, Kashid Beach is a popular yet tranquil destination on the Konkan coast. Known for its pristine white sands and clear blue waters, Kashid offers a serene environment perfect for relaxation. The beach is lined with casuarina trees, providing ample shade for a leisurely picnic. Activities like swimming, sunbathing, and horse riding are popular here, but the beach never feels overcrowded. The nearby Phansad Wildlife Sanctuary adds to the allure, offering nature trails and bird watching opportunities.

Diveagar Beach, approximately 160 km from Pune, is a hidden gem that remains relatively unexplored by tourists. The beach stretches for about 6 km, with soft sands and gentle waves making it ideal for a peaceful stroll. Diveagar is also famous for its ancient Suvarna Ganesh Temple and the migratory seabirds that visit the area. The serene atmosphere and minimal commercial activity make Diveagar Beach a perfect spot for those seeking solitude.

About 150 km from Pune, Shrivardhan Beach is known for its long, clean shoreline and calm waters. This beach is perfect for a quiet retreat, with fewer tourists compared to other popular beaches. The scenic beauty of Shrivardhan, combined with its historical significance as the hometown of the Peshwas, offers a unique blend of relaxation and cultural exploration. Visitors can also enjoy water sports like boating and parasailing in the calm waters.

Harihareshwar Beach, situated around 170 km from Pune, is a serene coastal destination known for its religious significance. The Harihareshwar Temple, dedicated to Lord Shiva, attracts pilgrims from all over the region. The beach itself is quiet and pristine, offering a peaceful setting for meditation and relaxation. The surrounding hills and lush greenery add to the scenic beauty, making Harihareshwar an ideal spot for nature lovers.

Located about 160 km from Pune, Murud Beach is famous for its clear waters and golden sands. The beach is relatively less crowded, making it perfect for a quiet getaway. One of the main attractions near Murud Beach is the historic Murud-Janjira Fort, accessible by boat. The fort's intriguing history and stunning architecture make it a must-visit. The beach also offers water sports like jet skiing and banana boat rides for those looking for a bit of adventure.

Surrounded by lush greenery, Kihim Beach stands out from other Indian coastal destinations. Just a 3.5-hour drive from the city, Kihim has gained popularity among young travellers. The beach boasts clean water and is remarkably well-kept. It offers an ideal beach getaway for those seeking relaxation, leisurely strolls along the sand, and sunset views. Bird watching enthusiasts will find ample opportunities as well.

Wildlife photography often captures the majestic and awe-inspiring aspects of nature, but sometimes, it also reveals the humorous side of the animal kingdom. The Comedy Wildlife Photography Awards celebrate these moments, showcasing the funniest and most entertaining images of wildlife. Here are ten award-winning images that have brought smiles and laughter to people around the world.Image: Jan Piecha/Instagram

Captured by Ken Jensen in Yunnan, China, this image shows a golden silk monkey in a rather uncomfortable position. Taken in August 2020, the monkey appears to be in pain as it sits on a wire, creating a comical yet relatable scene. This photo won the Overall Winner award in 2021, highlighting the lighter side of wildlife.Image: Ken Jensen/Instagram

Andrea Zampatti’s photo of a dormouse seemingly laughing was taken in Italy’s Abruzzo National Park in 2016. The dormouse, perched on a flower, looks like it is having a hearty laugh, making it an instant favorite. This image won the Creatures of the Land category in 2017, charming viewers with its joyful expression.Image: Andrea Zampatti/Instagram

Mark Fitzpatrick’s hilarious shot of a turtle giving the camera what looks like a rude gesture was taken at Lady Elliot Island, Australia, in 2020. The turtle’s timing and the angle of the shot make it appear as if it is flipping the bird, earning it the title of the People’s Choice Award in 2020.Image: greenme_it/Instagram

Arthur Telle Thiemann captured a grinning parrotfish in the Canary Islands in 2019. The fish’s wide, toothy smile is both endearing and amusing, making it a standout entry. This photo won the Underwater category in 2019, showcasing the playful side of marine life.Image: thecrankycamera/Instagram

Mary McGowan’s image of a surprised squirrel was taken in Florida, USA, in 2018. The squirrel’s wide-eyed expression and raised paws make it look like it has been caught doing something mischievous. This photo won the Overall Winner award in 2018, delighting audiences with its comedic timing.Image: BBC/Facebook

John Speirs captured a pigeon with leaves perfectly placed on its head, making it look like it’s wearing a hat. This humorous image won the Highly Commended award in 2021, showcasing the whimsical side of wildlife.

Arthur Trevino’s photo shows a prairie dog appearing to fend off a bald eagle in mid-attack. The prairie dog’s stance and the timing of the shot make it look like a martial arts move, earning it the Highly Commended award in 2021.

Vicki Jauron's image captures a delightful and humorous moment of an elephant enjoying a mud bath on the shores of Lake Kariba in Zimbabwe. In this image, the elephant appears to have face-planted into the mud, creating a comical scene that highlights the playful and carefree nature of these majestic animals. The photograph, part of a series, showcases the elephant’s sheer joy and exuberance as it indulges in this muddy activity, bringing a smile to viewers’ faces and celebrating the lighter side of wildlifeImage: Vicki Jauron/Comedy Wildlife Photography Awards

“Peekaboo” by Shane Keena is a delightful and humorous photograph that captures an owl seemingly playing a game of peekaboo. Taken in California, USA, this image won the Creatures of the Air category in the 2018 Comedy Wildlife Photography Awards. The owl’s surprised expression as it peeks out from below adds a touch of whimsy to the scene, showcasing the lighter and more endearing side of wildlife. Image: Shane Keena/Instagram

Comedian Daniel Fernandes faced significant backlash after posting a video that mocked the Jain community during one of his stand-up comedy shows in Hyderabad. The controversial joke quickly sparked outrage on social media, prompting Daniel to remove the video and issue a public apology via his social media platforms. However, despite his apology, the situation escalated as Daniel started receiving threatening calls and messages. BJP MLA T Raja Singh even released a video threatening physical violence against Daniel. In response to the mounting controversy and safety concerns, Daniel made the decision to cancel his upcoming show and further apologized through a video statement.

Hampi, once the capital of the powerful Vijayanagara empire, is located on the southern bank of the Tungabhadra River, some 340km from Bengaluru. The city's temples are renowned for their grand scale, intricate ornamentation, exquisite carvings, impressive pillars, and stunning pavilions. These temples showcase a rich array of iconographic and traditional depictions, including scenes from the Ramayana and the Mahabharata.

Badami, a town immersed in history, is renowned for its architectural wonders, caves, natural beauty, and rock-cut temples. The Badami Caves complex, a potential UNESCO World Heritage Site, is considered one of the finest examples of rock-cut monuments in India. Badami offers visitors a glimpse into Karnataka's rich cultural heritage, making it an ideal destination for art and nature enthusiasts.

Jog Falls, nestled within the lush forests of Sagara, Karnataka, is formed by the Sharavathi River cascading over four stunning waterfalls: Raja, Rani, Rover, and Rocket. As the second-highest plunge waterfall in India, Jog Falls is a spectacular sight, with an enormous volume of water plummeting from a height of 829 feet every second.

Kabini, a protected forest area named after the Kabini River, connects Nagarhole, Bandipur, and Mudumalai. It is one of the largest and most vibrant forest areas in India and a beloved destination for wildlife enthusiasts. The best time to visit Kabini is during the dry season, from October to June.

Nandi Hills, situated approximately 60 kilometers from Bengaluru, is a picturesque destination that offers a peaceful retreat from the city's chaos. Known for its breathtaking sunrises, lush greenery, and historical significance, Nandi Hills is an ideal getaway for nature lovers, adventure enthusiasts, and history buffs. The best time to visit is between September and February when the weather is pleasant and cool.

Coorg, also known as Kodagu, is an administrative district in Karnataka renowned for its natural beauty. Situated on the eastern slopes of the Western Ghats, Coorg is the perfect place for hiking, bird-watching, or simply immersing oneself in nature. The region boasts rivers, waterfalls, a national park, a wildlife resort, Buddhist monasteries, and more, making it an ideal destination for those seeking a serene location.

The Mysore Palace, also known as Amba Vilas Palace, is a stunning architectural marvel designed by British architect Henry Irwin. The three-storied stone edifice, built of fine gray granite, features deep pink marble domes dominated by a five-storied 145-foot tower with a gilded dome topped by a single golden flag. The palace showcases the classic Indo-Saracenic style, with its façade adorned with onion domes, turrets, minarets, cupolas, canopies with arches, intricate balconies, porches, and colonnades.

Ramanagara, located about 100 km northeast of Mysore on the Bangalore-Mysore road, is distinguished by its dramatic rocky formations, outcrops, and stark hills. This beautiful place gained popularity after the filming of the movie Sholay and has become a favorite among adventure sports enthusiasts. Ramanagara offers numerous opportunities for rock climbing, rappelling, and bouldering, as well as a temple dedicated to Rama, which can be reached by climbing about 350 steps.

Mughlai cuisine is rich in flavours and aromas, which became part of the Indian food scenario as early as the 15th century AD. From vegetarian to non-vegetarian dishes, they brought in a lot of flavours that revolve around the use of whole spices. Here’s a list of 10 dishes that are no less than the gifts of the Mughals to India. (Images Courtesy: istock)

For the uninitiated, Qorma originated in Persia, and was later adopted by Rajput chefs in Akbar's kitchen; later, it was termed Korma, after the Rajput tribe Kurma. This popular recipe is made with chicken pieces cooked in rich and creamy gravy.
Kebabs travelled from Turkey to India towards the end of the 14th century and are a delectable treat made with boneless chicken skewered and cooked over an open flame.
Another popular dish from Mughlai cuisine is Mutton Seekh Kebab, made with minced mutton.
It's a bread recipe made with refined flour, stuffed with onions, herbs, meat, and spices.
It has also become a part of Mughlai cuisine. It is made with boiled eggs and minced meat and is best served with rice.

It is said that this kebab was created for a Lucknow Nawab, who could not chew properly, and that is when this melt-in-the-mouth kebab was made. It is best paired with flaky tandoori roti, naan, or lachha paratha.
It's a rice, meat, and spice dish that became popular in the 16th century and is now available in many variations.
This is a mutton meat preparation that was introduced to India by the Mughals and has now become a staple of India.
The dish was consumed by Mughal emperors after morning prayers and was traditionally made with mutton stuffed with juicy bone marrow. It is best served with naan and rice.
It's a dessert treat made with rabdi, or thickened milk, fried bread slices, kesar, malai, and roasted nuts.

Starting the week on a productive note sets the tone for success ahead. Here are ten effective ways to make your Monday more productive:
Getty Images
Spend a few minutes planning your Monday. Create a to-do list prioritizing tasks for the day. This helps you hit the ground running when Monday arrives, reducing stress and increasing efficiency.
Getty Images

Begin your Monday morning with a clear focus and determination. Arrive a bit earlier than usual to settle in, review your plan, and prepare mentally for the day. Early mornings often provide a quieter, distraction-free environment conducive to productivity.
Getty Images

Identify and prioritize the most critical tasks on your to-do list. Addressing them early in the day ensures they receive your best energy and attention. Completing important tasks first also alleviates pressure later in the day.
Getty Images

Minimize interruptions and distractions to maintain focus throughout the day. Consider silencing non-essential notifications, closing unnecessary tabs, and setting specific times to check emails and messages. Creating a distraction-free environment enhances productivity significantly.
Getty Images

Schedule short breaks between tasks to recharge and maintain mental clarity. Breaks can include a short walk, stretching exercises, or simply stepping away from your workspace. These pauses rejuvenate your mind and prevent burnout, improving overall productivity.
Getty Images

Keep your workspace tidy and organized to minimize time spent searching for documents or supplies. Use folders, trays, or digital tools to manage documents and tasks efficiently. An organized workspace fosters a clear mind and enhances productivity.
Getty Images

Experiment with productivity techniques such as the Pomodoro Technique (working in focused intervals with breaks) or time-blocking (allocating specific time slots for tasks). Finding a method that suits your work style enhances productivity and time management.
Getty Images

Maintain a positive mindset and approach your tasks with enthusiasm. Celebrate small accomplishments throughout the day to stay motivated. Positive thinking boosts productivity and resilience, helping you navigate challenges effectively.
Getty Images

Incorporate mindfulness practices into your day to reduce stress and improve focus. Practice deep breathing, meditation, or mindful walking to enhance mental clarity and productivity. Mindfulness techniques promote a calm and centered mindset.
Getty Images

At the end of your Monday, take a few moments to reflect on your achievements and challenges. Review your progress against your weekly goals and adjust your plan if necessary. Planning ahead for the rest of the week sets you up for continued productivity and success.
Getty Images

Focus on one task at a time to maximize efficiency and accuracy. Multitasking can lead to mistakes and decreased productivity. Prioritize tasks and complete them sequentially to maintain quality and momentum.
Getty Images

Allocate specific time blocks for different tasks and activities throughout the day. Schedule focused work sessions with breaks in between to maintain productivity and prevent burnout. Time blocking helps manage your time effectively and improves task completion rates.
Getty Images

Acknowledge and celebrate your accomplishments at the end of the day. Recognize your efforts and achievements, no matter how small. Positive reinforcement boosts morale and motivates you to continue striving for success.
Getty Images

The article discusses the political tenure of Naveen Patnaik, focusing on both his intangible and tangible contributions to Odisha. It contrasts these achievements with perceived administrative shortcomings and critiques, culminating in the BJP's electoral victory which ended Patnaik's long-standing rule.
Naveen Patnaik’s legacy – Hype and reality

As the dust of months-long election campaigning settles and the first BJP government takes over the reins in Odisha, the most important question that pops into one’s mind is about the legacy of Naveen Patnaik, the ex-Chief Minister of Odisha who rode the political scene of the state like a Colossus for about two and half decades.

Naveen was a larger-than-life figure while he was the CM. His was a carefully built persona-not responsible for wrongs committed by his administration and party but the progenitor of every welfare measure and development initiative taken during his tenure. Now that he is no more at the helm of Odisha’s affairs and his party BJD’s overwhelming presence is a thing of the past, this is the time to dispassionately assess his contributions to Odisha.

Let’s talk about his intangible contributions first. Even his worst enemies will admit that Naveen is gentlemanliness personified. He carried himself with dignity and never used harsh words against his adversaries. Because of the sophistication and grace that he exuded, he was popular in the national media thus saving Odias from any taunt about their CM while interacting with non-Odias, unlike the Bengalis who have to face embarrassment when non-Bengalis mock the various utterances and pronunciational gaffes of their CM Mamata Banerjee. Further, Naveen had a clean image and no corruption allegation was levelled against him personally.

Coming to his tangible contributions to Odisha, his topmost achievement was navigating through natural disasters like cyclones which hit Odisha frequently. He knew well that it was the inept handling of the affairs post the super cyclone of 1999 by the then Congress Government that brought the alliance of BJD and BJP to power under his leadership. Odisha under his stewardship earned praise for evacuating citizens to safety during the cyclones of Phailin and Fani which hit the state in 2013 and 2019 respectively. Though poverty levels in Odisha still remain high, the state has gradually come down in the list of states having high multi-dimensional (with equally weighted three dimensions of health, education and standard of living) poverty. As per the document called National Multi-dimensional Poverty Index-A Progress Review 2023 published by Niti Ayog, in the list of states with the percentage of the total population who are multi-dimensionally poor, Odisha stood eighth.

This is a vast improvement from the situation about 3 decades back when Odisha used to be among the top 1-2 poorest states of India.  Naveen government also promoted the national game of Hockey in a big way hosting the Men’s Hockey World Cup Tournament more than once, thus bringing Odisha to national glare. BJD Government is also credited with launching initiatives like Biju Swasthya Kalyan Yojana (BSKY) and strengthening Mission Shakti for providing free healthcare to poorer sections of the populace and empowering women from disadvantaged backgrounds, respectively.

But many were unimpressed by the progress achieved by Odisha under the stewardship of Naveen Patnaik considering the long period of almost a quarter century of BJD rule.  It was felt among broad sections of the citizenry that during his five continuous terms, the state could have achieved much more. For example, very few industries were set up and employment opportunities were created during Naveen’s 24-year rule. Notwithstanding the ridiculously low unemployment rate of about 0.90% in 2023 as reported by the Centre for Monitoring the Indian Economy (CMIE), droves of young people leave Odisha every year to do menial jobs in various other states of India.

The reason for the reported low unemployment figure in Odisha is said to be not too many young unemployed Odias staying in the state, having shifted to other states for work. Further, Naveen’s uninterrupted reign of 24 years brought its associated malaises of rampant corruption, goonda raj and general degradation in the area of law and order. Though the capital city of Bhubaneswar saw development, much of the interior regions of the state remained mired in poverty and under-development.

But what actually did the BJD was the factor of perception about the governance model dominated by serving and former bureaucrats. The role of Tamil Nadu-born V. K Pandian, ex-IAS and aide of Naveen who joined the BJD a few months back became the most lethal arrow in the quiver of the main opposition BJP. Considered to be the ‘Super Chief Minister’ of Odisha by friends and foes of BJD, Pandian welded enormous power due to his exclusive access to Mr. Patnaik. With Naveen confined to his residence due to health factors, Pandian became the sole star campaigner for BJD who crisscrossed the state addressing gatherings unaccompanied by any important BJD leader.

There was credible apprehension in the minds of a vast number of Odias that considering Pandian’s vice-like grip on the ruling party and government not to mention Naveen himself, the former would succeed Mr. Patnaik should BJD return to power. BJP exploited this chink in the armour of the ruling party and made Odia Asmita (identity) the major campaign issue. Naveen’s reluctance to learn Odia despite being the CM for so long also came in handy to BJP to add credibility to the charge that Odia identity is under threat. This poll plank of BJP set the cat among the pigeons and Naveen had to clarify that his successor would be chosen by the people of the state. But by that time, it was already late and a wave had started to build in favour of BJP which unseated Naveen after long 24 years of rule.

Considering the not-so-encouraging showings of the BJP in other states, its performance in both Lok Sabha elections (in which it won 20 out of 21 seats in the state) and assembly elections in Odisha was the jewel in the crown of its electoral success. However, the nascent BJP government can eclipse the positive aspects of Naveen’s legacy only by the glow of sustained all-round growth of Odisha coupled with the creation of ample job opportunities.
(DISCLAIMER: This is an opinion piece. The views expressed are the author’s own and have nothing to do with OTV’s charter or views. OTV does not assume any responsibility or liability for the same.)

An IAS aspirant in New Delhi was scammed of Rs 1.2 lakh after being lured to a cafe by a woman he met on Tinder. The woman, named Versha, left under the pretext of a family emergency, leaving the victim with an exorbitant bill. Investigations revealed a gang running similar schemes across major cities.
IAS aspirant scammed of Rs 1.2L after Tinder date in New Delhi

A civil service aspirant’s wish to find love on Tinder's popular dating app went terribly wrong after he was scammed of Rs 1.2L in the National Capital. When he swiped right on Tinder, he had no idea he was walking into a trap. Little did he know that he was walking into a sinister plot planned to scam single men looking for love on Tinder or other dating apps.

According to Delhi police, the victim had recently been matched with a girl named Versha. The girl called him to Black Mirror Café in East Delhi’s Vikas Marg area to celebrate her so-called birthday. At the café, the woman ordered some snacks, two cakes and four shots of non-alcoholic beverage.

The ‘date' was going well until Versha received a call and had to rush out to due a family emergency. The victim then finished the food alone and asked for the bill which left him stunned. He received a whopping Rs 1,21,917.70 bill for food that should not cost him more than Rs 1000.

When the victim disputed the bill, he was threatened and beaten up, forced to pay. Fearing for his life, the victim paid the money online that went to the café’s owner – 32-year-old Akshay Pahwa. Coming out of the café, he went straight to the cops and filed a case.

Shocking details later emerged during the investigation. During the investigation, Akshay who is a Class 10 fail revealed the modus operandi of their gang.                They have opened the café and use Versha, who also goes by the names of Ayesha, Noor and Afsan Parveen to lure men and then siphon off money from them.

Later, Versha was tracked down who was at another café on a ‘date’ with a man from Mumbai she had met on Shaadi.Com. Later, Versha revealed all the details to the cops. They catch up with men on dating and matrimonial apps and lure them to date.

Later, Versha feigns a family emergency and rushes out and her date is made to pay a huge amount in the name of the bill. Later, 15% of the money goes to Versha, 45% is divided among the table and café managers, and the remaining 40% to the owners.
Several such schemes are in play in Delhi-NCR, Mumbai, Bangalore and Hyderabad to extort money from unwitting victims, Delhi police said. Efforts are on to arrest other accused, the police added.

Speculations arise about the BJD's future as party leader Naveen Patnaik urges unity and strength amid signs of internal dissent and poor performance in the 2024 elections. The controversy surrounds VK Pandian's continued influence despite his retirement.

On Wednesday, the BJD elected Naveen Patnaik as the leader of the opposition (LoP) and the legislature party leader. It is for the first time that Naveen Patnaik, who ruled Odisha for 24 years as the Chief Minister, is now the Leader of the Opposition (LoP) in the Odisha Assembly.

Following the BJD's significant loss in the 2024 General Elections, VK Pandian is still seen as a central figure despite his retirement from active politics. Political analysts suggest that internal party dynamics and overconfidence led to their defeat, with continued delays in reviewing the election results.

Mohan Majhi, recently appointed as the Chief Minister, faces criticism alleging he was chosen to facilitate iron ore exploitation in Keonjhar, Odisha by Ambani and Adani. Critics ignore past unchecked mining abuses and instead focus on vilifying Majhi without awaiting his administrative actions.
In a candid moment during the oath-taking ceremony of newly elected MLAs in Odisha, former CM Naveen Patnaik acknowledged his defeat to BJP's Laxman Bag from Kantabanji.

The article discusses the political tenure of Naveen Patnaik, focusing on both his intangible and tangible contributions to Odisha. It contrasts these achievements with perceived administrative shortcomings and critiques, culminating in the BJP's electoral victory which ended Patnaik's long-standing rule.
As per reports, all 147 MLAs are scheduled to be administered oath on June 18 and June 19. The Odisha Assembly Speaker election is scheduled for June 20.

Newly-elected Khordha MLA Prashant Jagdev, released on interim bail, criticized BJD president Naveen Patnaik and defended bureaucrat-turned-politician VK Pandian after BJD's defeat in the 2024 elections. BJP won 78 out of 147 assembly seats. Jagdev thanked Khordha voters and attended the new government's swearing-in ceremony.
Patnaik reiterated that the 4.5 crore people of Odisha are his family and he will continue to serve them in whichever way he can.

Some leaders and critics were of the view that it was due to the IAS officer-turned-politician, that the ruling BJD lost the trust of the people. Prior to and during the elections, Pandian was making statements on issues by calling national and local media persons.

The article reflects on Naveen Patnaik's political tenure as he steps down, critiquing his governance and its impact on Odia culture and politics. It highlights his manipulative political strategies, possible corruption, and the perceived betrayal by his trusted aide, alongside the disillusionment with his secular claims.

Chief Minister Naveen Patnaik clarified that VK Pandian is not his successor, aiming to quell rumors and manage the damage this speculation caused to BJD's election prospects. Despite the announcement, skepticism remains among voters as BJD faces significant challenges in the ongoing elections.
At a presser in Bhubaneswar, Aparajita Sarangi alleged that Odisha’s power corridor, the third floor and the coterie group are involved in the conspiracy behind Prashant Jagdev’s arrest.
Going into the final phase of elections, political parties are organizing public meetings and rallies with an increased frequency.

Post the third phase of elections in Odisha, BJP, BJD, and Congress have started claiming potential victory and government formation. BJD's Naveen Patnaik is confident despite challenges, while BJP has cited increased support and high-profile visits as success factors. Conversely, Congress has positioned itself as an alternative amidst higher polling percentages.

India won the 2024 Men's T20 World Cup after a gripping final against South Africa at Kensington Oval. The victory ended an 11-year wait for a major trophy, sparking joyous celebrations across the nation. Key players like Rohit Sharma, Hardik Pandya, and Virat Kohli were visibly emotional as they celebrated this historic win.

Suryakumar Yadav's sensational boundary-line catch to dismiss David Miller in the T20 World Cup has reminded fans of Harleen Deol's similar feat. India's victory marked their first ICC championship win in 11 years, with netizens praising both players' catches for their skill and timing.

The Indian cricket team is stranded in Barbados after their T20 World Cup victory due to Hurricane Beryl, which has intensified into a Category 4 storm. The hurricane is causing flight delays and airport shutdowns, with severe weather warnings in effect across the region.

Anushka Sharma shared a heartfelt post for her husband Virat Kohli after India's T20 World Cup win against South Africa. Despite recent poor form, Kohli's crucial innings led to India's triumph. His partnership with Axar Patel and Shivam Dube was pivotal. Both Anushka and Virat expressed gratitude and love for each other following the victory.

Rohit Sharma's triumphant moment after the ICC T20 World Cup final, where he collapsed in joy, has captured the hearts of Indian cricket fans. Sharing an emotional Instagram post, Rohit reflected on the victory. His announcement of retirement from T20Is has left fans heartbroken.

Left-arm spin all-rounder Ravindra Jadeja announced his retirement from T20 Internationals after India's victory in the Men's T20 World Cup at Kensington Oval. Jadeja, a key player in the win against South Africa, follows Rohit Sharma and Virat Kohli in retiring from the format. He expressed gratitude for his career and committed to continuing in ODIs and Tests.

Renowned sand artist Sudarsan Pattnaik created a 20 ft long bat and 500 balls sculpture at Puri beach to congratulate Team India and captain Rohit Sharma for winning the T20 World Cup. His students helped create a World Cup trophy and Rohit Sharma's sculpture.

India's captain Rohit Sharma described winning the 2024 T20 World Cup as the pinnacle of his career. India secured a dramatic seven-run victory over South Africa in the final. Both Rohit and Virat Kohli announced their retirement from T20 internationals following this win. Rohit emotionally dedicated the triumph to coach Rahul Dravid for his immense contribution to Indian cricket.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi congratulated the Indian Cricket Team for their ICC Men's T20 World Cup 2024 victory. He praised Rohit Sharma, Virat Kohli, Hardik Pandya, Surya Kumar Yadav, and Jaspreet Bumrah for their performances. Modi also thanked coach Rahul Dravid.

India defeated South Africa by seven runs in a thrilling T20 World Cup final, ending their 17-year wait for a second title. The emotional victory saw captain Rohit Sharma and key players like Virat Kohli and Hardik Pandya shed tears of joy, marking a significant moment in Indian cricket history.

Celebrities from various fields, including politicians and film stars like Shashi Tharoor, Chiranjeevi, and Anupam Kher, celebrated India's incredible T20 World Cup victory against South Africa. The nation united with pride as notable figures expressed their joy and admiration for the Indian cricket team's stellar performance.

India captain Rohit Sharma announced his retirement from T20I cricket following India's triumphant World Cup win in Barbados. His decision comes after Virat Kohli also retired from T20Is. Rohit will continue to play ODIs and Tests, ending his T20I career as the format's highest scorer with five centuries.

Star batter Virat Kohli announced his retirement from T20 Internationals after leading India to their second T20 World Cup win. He played a crucial 59-ball 76-run innings, securing a Man of the Match award in his final T20I game.
Team India emerged victorious in the T20 World Cup after a thrilling final against South Africa at the Kensington Oval in Bridgetown, Barbados. India won by 7 runs.

Virat Kohli's timely fifty propelled India to a total of 176 for seven against South Africa in the T20 World Cup final. Kohli's 76 and Axar Patel's crucial 47 helped recover from early setbacks, including the dismissals of Rohit Sharma, Rishabh Pant, and Suryakumar Yadav.

The Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) has released the admit cards for the EPFO Personal Assistant Examinations 2024. Candidates can download their e-admit cards from the official UPSC website ahead of the examination scheduled for July 7, 2024.
UPSC EPFO PA Examination: Admit Cards released, check how to download
The Union Public Service Commission (UPSC) has released the admit cards for the EPFO Personal Assistant Examinations 2024.
Candidates who have applied for the examination can download their respective admit cards by visiting the official website at upsc.gov.in.
As per the official notification, the examination is scheduled for July 7, 2024, and will be held from 9:30 AM to 11:30 AM, lasting two hours.

Upon downloading the e-admit card, candidates are advised to carefully review it and promptly report any discrepancies to the UPSC. The commission will strive to upload the revised e-admit card as soon as possible in such cases.
The commission also stated that candidates who do not present their e-admit card at the allotted venue will not be permitted to take the examination.
Visit the official UPSC website at upsconline.nic.in
Click on the link titled 'E-Admit Card for Personal Assistant in Employees’ Provident Fund Organisation, 2024’
Click on the UPSC EPFO Admit Card 2024 link.
Enter your login credentials (Registration number or Roll number)
Review the Admit Card displayed on the screen
Download and print a hard copy for future reference

The BCCI has shortlisted Gautam Gambhir and W.V. Raman for the new head coach of the Indian men's cricket team, set to start their role from the Sri Lanka series beginning July 27. This follows India's T20 World Cup win and marks the end of Rahul Dravid's tenure.

Cricket returns to Barabati Stadium in Cuttack with an ODI between India and England scheduled for February 9, 2025. This match is part of the BCCI's announced fixtures for Team India's 2024-25 international home season.
CAC members will be in for a big dilemma over picking one between Gambhir and Raman. With Raman’s experience and his rather impressive interview for the head coach role, BCCI may spring a surprise.

Former India cricketer Gautam Gambhir is poised to become the next head coach for the India men's cricket team, with an interview scheduled in Mumbai at BCCI headquarters. His demands, including full command of the team and separate teams for different formats, have been reportedly accepted by the BCCI.
The report stated that the former southpaw is ready to take on the challenges to coach the Men in Blue in all the three formats.

A report published in some sections of media suggested that a 'very high-profile owner of an IPL franchise, who is very close to the BCCI top brass told that former India star's appointment as Indian cricket team coach is a 'done deal and the announcement will come soon'.
However, it is not clear at this stage whether the BCCI has received any applications from genuine candidates who are interested in the responsibility.

Legendary Australian cricketer and the current head coach of the Delhi Capitals Ricky Ponting has confirmed that BCCI had approached him for the job. However, it is highly unlikely that he would apply for the job.
BCCI is not ready to give up on Fleming yet. Dhoni is likely to be their last throw of the dice.

Some of the IPL franchise head coaches, who have been a part of the T20 league for quite some time, are likely to be in fray.

Mohan Majhi's new government started well with initial actions like opening Lok Seva Bhavan to journalists and Lord Jagannath temple to the public. However, issues arose with delayed portfolio allocations and excessive bureaucratic control, suggesting need for democratic reforms and better leadership distribution.
Odisha CM Mohan Majhi

The first 24 hours after the swearing in went just fine. The first cabinet meeting – without portfolios allocated to the newly inducted ministers – took place within a couple of hours and approved the four major poll promises of the party. The gates of the Lok Seva Bhavan were opened for journalists - after over four years – the same evening. And all four gates of the Lord Jagannath temple in Puri were thrown open to the public the next morning – again after four years. Mohan Majhi, the new Chief Minister, did the rounds of the statues of Odia icons and paid floral tributes to them, in the company of his two deputies - Kanak Vardhan Singhdeo and Pravati Parida - the morning after. The optics were unexceptionable.

But having begun well, the new BJP government has faltered at the very first hurdle. First, the allocation of portfolios was delayed by three full days. And when it finally came, the most important portfolio – finance – was conspicuously missing in the list of departments allocated to ministers, requiring the release of a revised list by Raj Bhavan within an hour of the first. This was an eminently avoidable embarrassment, presumably caused by lack of homework and attention to detail.

But the bigger embarrassment for the government was the delay of three days in the allocation of portfolios, which has traditionally been done within a few hours of the swearing in. The inordinate delay deepened the impression in the minds of the people that the Mohan Majhi government will have no freedom to act on its own and will be ‘remote controlled’ by the ruling party’s central leadership. Some of the ministers unwittingly buttressed this impression by expressing gratitude to the party’s central leaders, apart from the CM, for giving them the responsibility of the department. Dispelling this impression that every major decision of the Majhi government will be taken – or vetted – in Delhi, therefore, should be the most immediate task for the new dispensation.

The second biggest challenge for the new government will be reining in the bureaucrats, who had been allowed – and even encouraged – to exceed their brief during the long running previous regime. The system that Naveen Patnaik had put in place, where bureaucrats call all the shots while elected representatives, including ministers, look on helplessly is not only untenable, but is completely against the spirit of democratic governance. A complete overhaul of the skewed bureaucrat-legislator(minister) equation thus should be one of the first tasks on the Majhi government’s agenda. But with experience of running a department at a premium in the new government (half the ministers are first time MLAs), this is easier said than done.

There is no real pattern that emerges from the distribution of portfolios on Saturday evening, suggesting that not much thought has gone into it. The CM has kept far too many departments, including the key ones of Home and Finance – with himself. With so many departments to look after, he would hardly get time to do what he needs to do most: give leadership to his team and to constantly monitor and review its performance. Some of the departments could perhaps have been allocated to senior leader Suresh Pujari, whose cupboard looks rather barren with only Revenue and Disaster Management. While he is a first time MLA, he has been in politics long enough to do justice to his ministerial duties. He was, after all, the top contender for the CM’s post before Mohan Majhi emerged out of the blue. It is, of course, possible that Majhi would shed some of the departments that he currently holds when the ministry is expanded and new ministers are inducted. Here again, the government could have avoided unnecessary speculation and intrigue by inducting all 22 ministers in one go.

Every new government deserves – and usually gets – a ‘honeymoon period’ of a few months before judgments are passed on its performance. But thanks to a vicious, no-holds-barred campaign that has uprooted a 24-year old tree with deep roots in the soil, the Majhi government is unlikely to get such courtesy. In fact, the barbs against the new government had started flying thick and fast even before it had been sworn in – and even before Majhi had been named the Chief Minister. It was, of course, only to be expected for two reasons. First, the Naveen Patnaik government might have gone out of power; but those who helped sustain it for so long haven’t lost any of their power. Second, a newly ‘freed’ media will subject the Majhi government to greater – and much stricter – scrutiny than it has ever dared to do during the previous regime.
The Majhi government thus has its task cut out.
(DISCLAIMER: This is an opinion piece. The views expressed are the author’s own and have nothing to do with OTV’s charter or views. OTV does not assume any responsibility or liability for the same.)

The Staff Selection Commission (SSC) has released the notification for the Multi-Tasking Non-Technical Staff and Havaldar Examination 2024. Interested candidates can download the notification from ssc.gov.in.
The application process has already commenced and the deadline to submit the application form is May 7.
Prospective candidates are encouraged to submit their applications via the official website of the Staff Selection Commission at ssc.nic.in.

As we explore the landscape of 2024, these positions call for a unique blend of educational excellence and leadership acumen. Each avenue provides a distinct pathway for individuals not only seeking professional growth but also aiming to contribute meaningfully to the progress of the nation.
Candidates who participated in Paper II can complete the submission of their option cum preference form via the official SSC website at ssc.nic.in.
The Commission had conducted Computer Based Examination for the above-mentioned positions from September 1 to September 14, 2023 at different centers across the country
Individuals who participated in the examination can now access the comprehensive vacancies list on the SSC's official website at ssc.nic.in.
The application procedure is expected to start on November 24, with the deadline for submitting applications set for December 31.
The deadline for application submission is within 14 days from the date of advertisement publication in the newspaper.
Prospective candidates can apply through the official website at www.ossc.gov.in.
Candidates, who had appeared for the exam, can now check the SSC CGL Tier 1 result by visiting the official website at, ssc.nic.in
The SSC has brought some amendments to the negative marking rules with respect to the advertisement released on July 26, 2023.
Those who are interested can submit their applications online by visiting the official website ssc.nic.in.
The application process has already commenced and the last date to submit the application form is September 12.
For detailed information, candidates are encouraged to visit the official SSC website at ssc.nic.in.

Here is the fortnightly astrological prediction for Aquarius, the eleventh astrological sign in the zodiac. Professionals in the media sector are likely to gain recognition for their work, marking a fruitful phase in their careers. Legal battles that have been ongoing may see favourable outcomes, bringing a sense of accomplishment and relief. Check what more you can expect.

Family members are likely to spend quality time together. Media professionals are likely to gain recognition for their work. Success in ongoing legal battles is likely. Happiness is likely to be experienced in financial growth. Health issues related to bones are likely to be addressed.

Victory is likely to be achieved in old legal cases. Opportunities are likely to arise for personal development. The family atmosphere is likely to remain peaceful. Good health is likely to be experienced. Stubbornness in relationships is likely to diminish.

They are generally of moderate height, very good looking with a handsome face, perfect body features, brown to dark complexion, smooth hair with women having perfect curvy figure. Diseases related to blood impurity, nervousness, weakness, flatulence, diabetes, mental disorders, stomach diseases, intestinal problems, bladder problems, period problems in women etc are common in Aquarians.

They are usually intelligent, religious, quick-tempered, cunning, cruel and violent. They are calm and graceful and are quite good in poetry and art skills. They do not allow a single instance of corruption before their eyes. They show-off, but face the consequences in the next moment. They consider themselves to be judgmental.

They generally make friends based on their own selfish needs. They keep everything confidential and just pretend to be friends. They do not choose to have relationships with people that do not serve their interests, but they maintain a lasting relationship with those they make friendship with.
They know their enemies. Many a time they are harmed by their enemies but when attacked, they become harsh and violent and try to suppress them by force.

They generally excel as writers, medicine professionals, law enforcement and in spy/intelligence agencies, electrical department professionals, agents, actors, singer, poet etc. In business, they mostly do well in agriculture, mining, transportation, iron and steel, oil, cosmetics etc.

Lack of understanding with spouse is observed. Lot of quarrels happen between both partners. They spend their days in turmoil because of completely unstable love and romantic affairs. But they are very good at understanding human character. They often prefer a love marriage and are most compatible with Aries, Taurus, Gemini, Virgo, Libra, Sagittarius, Capricorn and Aquarius.
They are very lustful and highly skilled in the field of love and romance which makes their married life quite happy and satisfied. They prefer living a life filled with romance and passion.

They are calm, simple, helpful, wise and treat all members of the family equally. They are very devoted to their family especially to their siblings, fathers and value every member and do everything after consultation with the head of the family.

Even if they earn good in life, they do not get to enjoy it. They are sad when they are old. Even if they inherit their father's wealth, they sell it to someone else without being able to enjoy it. The financial condition is often not good.

They are generally ambitious and have the skill of a sweet tongue which helps them achieve their goals. They are able to capture and use people to their own advantage and do various things through them for own benefit. Self-improvement is their main goal. The habit of showing off to others by covering up their mistakes keeps them away from their true self.

The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has forecast heavy rainfall and thunderstorms in several parts of Odisha over the next 48 hours. A yellow warning has been issued, with surface winds expected to reach 40-50 kmph along the North Odisha coast.

The India Meteorological Department forecasts heavy to very heavy rainfall over Northwest and Northeast India, including Delhi, in the next 4-5 days. The Southwest Monsoon has advanced further into East Uttar Pradesh and parts of West Uttar Pradesh. Conditions are favorable for its progression into more regions.

A low-pressure area has formed over the Northwest Bay of Bengal, likely to affect parts of Odisha with heavy rainfall. The IMD has issued a yellow warning for nine districts, advising fishermen against venturing into the sea.

Five individuals died from lightning strikes in Odisha's Bargarh and Balangir districts, with three fatalities under a tree and two in a paddy field. The Chief Minister announced an ex-gratia of Rs 4 lakh for the victims' families and ensured free treatment for the injured.

The IMD forecasts heavy to very heavy rainfall across various regions of India, including the West Peninsular Coast and Northeast India, from June 27-30. Enhanced rainfall due to cyclonic activities and Western Disturbance is also expected in Northwest and Central India.

A report indicates over 60% of marginal farmers in India suffered significant crop losses due to extreme weather like droughts and heavy rains in the past five years. The study calls for enhanced climate resilience, better financial services, and diversified agricultural practices.

The Odisha government has instructed district collectors and municipal commissioners to prepare for potential floods during the monsoon, following an IMD forecast of intense rainfall. Measures include strategic deployments and ensuring drainage systems are clear to handle the increased water flow.

Monsoon has arrived in Odisha, alleviating heatwave conditions with widespread rainfall. The Regional MeT Department issued a yellow warning for nine districts, forecasting rain, thunderstorms, and lightning. This rainfall is crucial for starting Kharif cultivation but varies significantly across districts.
The Monsoon, active over Odisha, is predicted to bring heavy rainfall in Kandhamal, Ganjam, and Gajapati districts within 24 hours.

The Monsoon has reached 24 out of 30 districts in Odisha, causing rainfall in several areas. The IMD predicts heavy rainfall and thunderstorms with gusty winds up to 40 KMPH across the state over the next three days.
The southwest monsoon is advancing into parts of Koraput, Nabarangpur, Rayagada, and Gajapati in Odisha.
The cyclonic circulation over the west-central Bay of Bengal adjoining Coastal Andhra Pradesh has become less marked, said IMD.

The IMD predicts below-normal June rainfall across India, impacting regions already suffering from heatwaves. Southern and northeastern states expect normal to above-normal rains. The delayed monsoon progression affects agriculture, crucial for the economy and industrial demand.

The IMD issued a 'yellow warning' for several districts in Odisha, predicting thunderstorms with lightning and gusty winds up to 40 kmph, alongside heavy rainfall. This alert follows recent rains that relieved hot conditions in areas including Bhubaneswar.
Heavy rain accompanied by gusty winds and lightning was reported in different parts of Bhubaneswar in the afternoon today.

Tensions flared in Belanta village, Cuttack, after a violent clash led to bombs being hurled. Several people were injured, and police have been deployed to maintain order. The incident follows earlier conflicts during Holi.

Ratna Bhandar, the treasure trove of Lord Jagannath, will be opened soon, said Odisha Chief Minister Mohan Majhi on Sunday. He said this while addressing a special function organised in Bhubaneswar to felicitate newly elected BJP MPs and MLAs.

Bars and pubs in Bhubaneswar are operating beyond permissible hours, prompting the Excise Commissioner to direct officials for inspections and legal actions. Social media posts exposed these violations, leading to increased surveillance and potential hefty fines or license cancellations.

Laxmisagar Police Station in Bhubaneswar registered the first case under new criminal laws, replacing British-era statutes. The incident involved an attempted murder on Gauranga Charan Das. Union Home Minister Amit Shah highlighted key changes, emphasizing crimes against women and children.

At least eight workers are in critical condition following a carbon monoxide gas leak at Rourkela Steel Plant. The incident occurred during repair work at blast furnace number-5. Injured workers are receiving treatment in ICU at Ispat General Hospital.

With the Rath Yatra of Lord Jagannath in Puri nearing, preparations are nearly complete. Odisha Law Minister Prithviraj Harichandan announced that CM Mohan Majhi will review final arrangements. The event focuses on discipline, amenities for women, and resolving VIP movement issues. President Droupadi Murmu is set to attend and participate in the celebrations.

The newly-elected BJP government in Odisha, under CM Mohan Majhi, has revived the public grievance cell after several years. Citizens from across the state are now able to present their issues directly to the CM. This marks a shift from the previous administration under Naveen Patnaik.

Three people were killed and nine injured in separate road accidents in Bhubaneswar, Rayagada, and Angul. Accidents involved an SUV hitting a divider, a car collision with bikers, and another fatal incident on NH-55.

Odia migrant workers from Jagatsinghpur, Cuttack, and Kendrapara are stranded in Dubai, alleging mental and physical torture, unpaid salaries, and passport confiscation. They appeal to Odisha CM Mohan Majhi and MP Baijayant Panda for urgent help.

Dengue cases in Odisha have doubled with the onset of monsoon, reaching 288 total cases by Thursday. Khordha district reported 80 of these cases, predominantly from urban areas. Health officials are focusing on awareness and preparation as more rain is expected.
This year's Rath Yatra on July 7, as many as 315 special trains will run to Puri, as Railway Minister Ashwini Vaishnaw announced after discussions with Odisha CM.

A ceiling collapse at Jatani Community Health Centre in Khordha injured a newborn baby and his mother. The accident occurred early Friday morning, causing panic. Both the mother and child were moved to another room and are safe. The family is demanding action against the contractor responsible for the hospital's redevelopment.
IAS officer Manoj Ahuja was appointed as the new chief secretary of Odisha, replacing Pradeep Kumar Jena.

As per reports, there was a heated exchange between both students over a trivial issue in the school. Subsequently, one among them lost his cool and stabbed the other with a sharp-edged weapon causing grievous injury.
After an inquiry by the Odisha Home Department into IPS officer Ashish Singh's whereabouts, DGP Arun Sarangi confirmed that Singh resumed duty on June 3.

The Biju Patnaik International Airport (BPIA) in Bhubaneswar may soon be privatised.As per reports published in some sections of national media, as many as 11 airports across the country may be privately managed soon. The reports stated that among the 11 airports, Bhubaneswar, Indore, Raipur and Trichy airports are likely be privatised. As a result, efforts will be made for the development and augmentation of these airports. The airports that are incurring losses will be given priority for privatisation. On the basis of profit and loss, a list of the airports will be made and accordingly, bidding will be done. If a company takes over an airport making profit, it also has to take responsibility of an airport incurring loss. However, the final decision regarding the elaborate bidding process will be taken in the cabinet meeting. Notably, BPIA is a profit-making airport and the air traffic is gradually increasing here. Adani Group is reportedly leading the race to take over BPIA. As per sources, the infrastructure of BPIA will be developed after privatisation and it will be better managed. Though the price of air travel will increase a little bit, the passengers will get better facilities.
Published: Odishatv Bureau
Last updated: 28 June 2024, 03:03 PM IST

Odisha faces delayed monsoon onset, causing prolonged hot and humid weather. The IMD forecasts potential advancement of the southwest monsoon and predicts thunderstorms and significant rainfall across various districts in the coming days.

There would be a gradual rise in maximum temperature (day temperature) by 2 to 3 degrees C during the next 3 days and no large change is expected thereafter at many places over the districts of Odisha.

Manorama Mohanty, director of IMD Bhubaneswar said, “The Southwest Monsoon usually arrives in Odisha towards the second week of June – 12th or 13th. We expect the Monsoon to touch south Odisha in the next three to four days. Till now, conditions are favourable."
The India Meteorological Department (IMD) on Saturday informed that there is every possibility of a drop in the maximum temperature in the coming days.
The maximum temperature settled at 45.2 degrees in Sambalpur which had recorded the highest temperature by 2:30 pm today.

A yellow warning for hot and humid conditions has also been issued for some districts of the state. IMD has also predicted thunderstorm activities in various parts of the state in the next couple of days.

Sujata Khatua from Bhadrak, Odisha, has entered the India Book of Records for writing road safety songs in memory of her deceased son Soumitra Mohanty, who died in a road accident.
Sujata Khatua
Sujata Khatua, a resident of Bhadrak town, has made it to the India Book of Records for writing songs in memory of her son who was killed in a road mishap.

Sujata’s son Soumitra Mohanty was in the final year of his MBBS. In a cruel joke of destiny, he was killed in a road accident in September last year. It was very difficult for Sujata to come to terms with her son’s untimely death.

While being immersed in sorrow, she started writing songs in the memory of her son. The theme of most of her songs is road safety and awareness. Soon, she became famous in her locality for her poems. Now, she has secured a place in the India Book of Records for writing songs on traffic rules awareness, in the memory of her son.
Also Read: 'Misguided by Google Maps,' 5 friends stranded in Odisha jungle for 11 hours

“After losing my son, I tried to write down whatever feelings came to me. I thought I would give expressions to my feelings. If something bad happens to us, we think God has done injustice to us. But, we human beings can’t understand God's plan. Our faith in Him shows a new path,’ said Sujata.

The bodies of farmer Rakesh Dodwa, his wife, and three children were discovered in their Alirajpur district home. Police suspect suicide but continue to investigate as no note was found.
Suicides
The bodies of a farmer, his wife, and three children were found in their house in a village in Alirajpur district of Madhya Pradesh on Monday, police said.
Prima facie, it is a case of suicide, an official said.

The bodies of Rakesh Dodwa (27), his wife Lalita Dodwa (25) and their sons Prakash (7) and Akshay (5) were found hanging next to each other from the ceiling of their kuchha house with rope, while the body of their daughter, Laxmi (9), was found lying on the floor, an official said.

Citing preliminary information, police had initially stated that all five bodies were hanging in the house. However, a villager later informed the police that the couple and their two sons were found hanging, while the girl's body was lying on the floor of their house in Ravdi village.
"The information about the death of five people at Ravdi village in Sondwa tehsil was received at 9.20 AM on Monday," the police official said.
A team headed by the Sub Divisional Officer of Police (SDOP) of Alirajpur has been constituted to probe the incident as no suicide note was found at the spot, he said.
Prima facie, the incident occurred between 7 pm on Sunday and 6 am on Sunday.
According to police, the family head Rakesh Dodwa was a farmer. He also used to work as a mason in Gujarat.

A dog squad and a forensic team have reached the spot and collected fingerprints. A forensic team from Indore is also reaching the spot, police said, adding that the postmortem of bodies is videographed.
(Except for the headline, this story, from a syndicated feed, has not been edited by Odishatv.in staff)

The government aims to develop an indigenous high-performance computing (HPC) processor, AUM, to become a global leader in supercomputing. At an event, C-DAC announced its partnership with MosChip Technologies and Socionext Inc. The chip will be based on Arm architecture using TSMC's 5nm technology.
The bodies of farmer Rakesh Dodwa, his wife, and three children were discovered in their Alirajpur district home. Police suspect suicide but continue to investigate as no note was found.

Prime Minister Narendra Modi stated that Digital India symbolizes an empowered nation by enhancing 'Ease of Living' and transparency. Celebrating nine years of the initiative, Modi highlighted the country's advancements in digital payments and public infrastructure, making it a global fintech leader.

Rahul Gandhi's first speech as Leader of Opposition in the Lok Sabha focused on philosophical and religious themes, sparking contentious debates. Despite expectations, he barely discussed the NEET paper leak issue. His comments on Hinduism and Agniveers led to several high-profile objections from Prime Minister Modi and other ministers.

In his first speech as Leader of the Opposition in Lok Sabha, Rahul Gandhi criticized the Agnipath scheme, alleging it treats soldiers as 'use and throw' labourers. Defence Minister Rajnath Singh rebutted these claims, emphasizing provisions for martyr status and compensation under the scheme.

Lt Gen Devendra Sharma took charge as the 25th General Officer Commanding-in-Chief of the Army Training Command (ARTRAC) in Shimla. With a prestigious military background and extensive experience, Lt Gen Sharma has held various significant command roles throughout his career.

India has urged Pakistan for the early release and repatriation of civilian prisoners and fishermen, including those who have completed their sentences. Both nations exchanged lists of prisoners under the bilateral Agreement on Consular Access 2008.

A Delhi court sentenced activist Medha Patkar to five months imprisonment and a Rs 10 lakh fine for criminal defamation against V.K. Saxena. The case dates back to 2001, when Saxena, now the Lieutenant Governor of Delhi, filed the suit accusing Patkar of harming his reputation.

Rahul Gandhi's first speech as Leader of the Opposition in Lok Sabha sparked chaos when he linked Hindus with violence, drawing strong protests from BJP MPs and interventions from PM Modi and Home Minister Amit Shah, who demanded an apology.

Union Home Minister Amit Shah announced that India's criminal justice system has become completely 'swadeshi' with the introduction of new laws replacing British-era ones. The new legislation reflects Indian ethos, aims to expedite justice, and includes stricter penalties for crimes such as gang rape and mob lynching.

A police constable, Lokanath, stabbed his wife Mamatha to death at the SP's office in Hassan district, Karnataka. The incident was triggered by a family dispute. Despite being rushed to the hospital, Mamatha succumbed to her injuries. Lokanath fled the scene and police are actively searching for him.

Food safety officials in Karnataka have discovered cancer-causing chemicals in Pani Puris. Out of 260 samples, 41 tested positive for carcinogenic agents like brilliant blue, sunset yellow, and tartrazine. Additionally, 18 samples were deemed unfit for consumption. The government warns of strict action against vendors violating food safety regulations.

The Indian government announced the 'Global IndiaAI Summit' to be held on July 3-4 in New Delhi. The event, chaired by India under the Global Partnership on Artificial Intelligence (GPAI), aims to foster collaboration and knowledge exchange among global AI stakeholders. It highlights India's commitment to ethical and inclusive AI growth.

Puri district is one of the most sacred pilgrimage sites for Hindus, Situated along the coast of Bay of Bengal in the state of Odisha. Puri is also known as Jagannath Puri. It is considered as one “Dhaam” among four holy “Dhaam” in India. The holy script of the Skanda Purana describes Puri as the resting place of Lord Vishnu. Apart from this Puri district is famous for its golden sea beach and black pagoda or sun temple of Konark. The famous heritage art village Raghurajpur is in this district, where artisans paint world famous Pattachitra painting. Puri Khaja, Khechuudi, Dalma has its own special flavor.

It is considered as one “Dhaam” among four holy “Dhaam” in India. The holy script of the Skanda Purana describes Puri as the resting place of Lord Vishnu. The famous heritage art village Raghurajpur is in this district, where artisans paint world famous Pattachitra painting. Puri Khaja, Khechuudi, Dalma has its own special flavor.

With the Rath Yatra of Lord Jagannath in Puri nearing, preparations are nearly complete. Odisha Law Minister Prithviraj Harichandan announced that CM Mohan Majhi will review final arrangements. The event focuses on discipline, amenities for women, and resolving VIP movement issues. President Droupadi Murmu is set to attend and participate in the celebrations.

The government will consult servitors, intellectuals and stakeholders post-Rath Yatra to implement the plans to make darshan at Srimandir more disciplined, said Odisha Law Minister Prithiviraj Harichandan
This year's Rath Yatra on July 7, as many as 315 special trains will run to Puri, as Railway Minister Ashwini Vaishnaw announced after discussions with Odisha CM.
The servitors of Puri Rath Yatra have called for a museum to conserve the wooden idols of 'Sakhi' and side deities.

Plans are underway to introduce an online slot booking system for darshan at Puri Srimandir. This initiative aims to alleviate long wait times for devotees by allowing them to register in advance. Currently, the proposal is in its early stages.
As Rath Yatra, ‘Nabajouban Darshan’ and ‘Netra Utsav’ are falling on the same day, the SJTA has taken the decision to not allow devotees to have ‘Nabajouban Darshan’.

As per the timetable fixed in the Chhatisha Nijog meeting, on July 7, after Gajapatai Maharaja Dibyasingha Deba’s ‘chhera panhara’ ritual at 4 PM, the ‘charamala phita’ will be held at 4.30 PM and then the chariot pulling will begin at 5 PM.
After the lavish bath on Snana Purnima, the deities are believed to develop a fever. Then they are taken in Anasara Pahandi to a sick room called ‘Anasara Ghara’.
According to a belief, the deities are dressed as Lord Ganesha to satisfy the followers of the Ganapatya sect.
Like us, Lord Jagannath also brushes teeth, consumes food, retires for the day after dinner, and also suffers from a fever.
Out of the 12 important festivals observed in Srimandir, Deva Snana Purnima or Snana Yatra is one of them.

The planned reopening of Puri Srimandir's Ratna Bhandar has sparked confusion and political debate after conflicting statements from the ASI and Odisha's Law Minister. With concerns about treasure security and lack of coordination cited, clarity remains elusive.

"As per the 2018 report, an inspection was done and cracks were observed, some stones had fallen... The condition was not good. In the laser scanning, cracks were also detected in the outer wall and joints"
The police administration in Puri is ramping up security for the Deva Snana Purnima on June 22, deploying 70 platoon forces and numerous officers to manage the expected increase in devotees.
This year the Rath Yatra falls on July 7. On the same day, the ‘Naba Jaubana Darshan’ and ‘Netrotsav’ of the deities are also falling.

Tensions flared in Belanta village, Cuttack, after a violent clash led to bombs being hurled. Several people were injured, and police have been deployed to maintain order. The incident follows earlier conflicts during Holi.
10 bombs hurled in Odisha
Palpable tension erupted at Belanta village under Tigiria police limits in Cuttack district after several bombs were hurled following a clash in the region on Monday.
Reportedly, a clash erupted between two groups of the village over past enmity yesterday. Later, late last night, more than 10 bombs were hurled.
Several persons have reportedly sustained injuries in the bombing incident.
Meanwhile, police personnel have been deployed in the village to avoid any untoward incident.
Earlier also, during Holi, the village had witnessed a group clash.
